newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish T-bill yields seen flat at mid-week auction.
newsitem.headline: Polish T-bill yields seen flat at mid-week auction.

text.p: Polish T-bill yields are expected to stay flat at Wednesday's 400 million zloty primary auction after the treasury froze minimum prices during previous auctions, dealers said on Tuesday.
Dealers said demand at the additional mid-week auction could double the treasury's offer but that foreign investor bids may be curbed by a relatively strong zloty.

"The ministry needs to fill a gap in the budget, so prices will not rise if this means rejecting most bids, but they are not likely to fall either," said Krzysztof Kozuchowski, T-bill dealer at ING bank in Warsaw.

Dealers expected many investors to test the ministry for higher yields but most said that minimum prices would likely stay flat at 81.85 for the benchmark 52-week T-bill and at 90.03 for the 26-week paper.
"Prices will be flat after the treasury showed that it will not let yields rise further," said Bartlomiej Kumela, dealer at Societe Generale in Warsaw.
On Tuesday the treasury released budget deficit figures for the first quarter, which showed a 3.96 billion zloty gap amounting to 32.4 percent of the planned 1997 shortfall.
